column5:
“The Five Best Cargobike Cities in Europe — and some Honorable Mentions” by Mikael Colville-Andersen
https://t.co/ohsHyR7g6D (excellent summary of cargo bike practices and possibilities) https://t.co/ubMqaRFIGx
This is going to be very good https://t.co/1wqy9pYAew

@tomcoates I gave up this morning and asked for an inspection copy (which reqd another form which unnecessarily took 15 mins to fill in, but hey). And yes I mail people my books all the time. Most of the issues here are bad UX and strategy, however, which is a bit lame for 2023
@dubber @unilibrary @ProQuest @Adobe If that's a Scandi beer, then it must've been a handsome return indeed.
#civicclock cc @bryanboyer

Another shout out for the new Circular Design Praxis project https://t.co/EuRzFjBLla with colleagues in Japan, and around which I wrote this contextual piece 'Spring to Autumn. Or, a ‘new metabolism’ for a circular society with Japanese characteristics' https://t.co/UpyZwvgeLm
(Of course the price of academic books is also appalling. Kindle editions at 150 dollars plus? And it’s not as if that goes to the writer.)

Online academic publishing is appalling. I get free access via @unilibrary but then the UX always falls apart. @ProQuest makes you use @Adobe Digital Editions, which is an embarrassment to all concerned. Sites for publishers like Taylor & Francis simply don’t work. What a mess.

@c_siggaard @bryanboyer As in crits and reviews? Not sure I did write something. And if I did, @bryanboyer would already know what I would say! I do remember a design publication (Disegno? Or equivalent) doing something about it? Will dig out. Also, this? https://t.co/05Ji9rhAOc

@TristanAR_ @BenPhillips_ANU @jryancollins Agreed on the second part (massively increased emphasis on sustainable public housing, via various means) but want to respectfully place a bit of caution on the first: as in, population growth rates are slowing, globally. We may already have a lot of the buildings we need.

@BenPhillips_ANU @TristanAR_ @jryancollins Yep. It was really about placing emphasis on the buildings we already have, rather than building anew. Also, whilst we need to hugely increase proportion of public and affordable housing either way, I’m suspicious of overall growth projections, given global population slowdown
(Aware of the irony of posting that to Twitter)

“surpluses are first directed to users; then, once they're locked in, surpluses go to suppliers; then once they're locked in, the surplus is handed to shareholders and the platform becomes a useless pile of shit…this is the enshittification lifecycle” https://t.co/ZJPGuYqkoL

@BenPhillips_ANU @TristanAR_ @jryancollins has led some great research in the carbon cost of new build in the UK https://t.co/ILgNdRXn1W ie building what’s promised would blow the whole carbon budget for the UK. Do we have equivalent research for Aus?

@BenPhillips_ANU @TristanAR_ Agreed with this. Land appreciates (generally), housing depreciates. And building is only cheap as we kick we can down the road on cost, and/or we privatise the profit and socialise the costs—infrastructure provision cost is huge, never mind environmental (+health etc) costs
And the main project site is here: https://t.co/EuRzFjBLla

I just wrote a piece about a new project I'm part of, called Circular Design Praxis, based out of Japan, but with an Asia-Pacific lens on circularity. Here's my essay contribution—hope you find it interesting, useful or otherwise provoking! https://t.co/V1iPhWbJfi
Something we’re proud to sponsor through our school - have a think about entering, and/or pass it on! https://t.co/OVNX8PRurI  https://t.co/OVNX8PRurI

(By focusing only on reinforcing current inequalities at the cost of future generations, environments and communities (evidence: https://t.co/LHwxylAMK1) it could be argued that these 20thC-based home-ownership policies are now essentially non-democratic)

“Homebuyers don’t need to pay a new tax, they need help to pay no tax whatsoever” (Allegedly, this is a Labour politician saying this, which shows how warped Australian politics has become due to a single-minded obsession with home-ownership) https://t.co/WdrO16Gvq0

“Howard, like the opinion writers in the Murdoch media, throws sand in your face so you cannot see what we are actually asking for: a right to be consulted about decisions that affect our lives, and a right to truth-telling and treaties” https://t.co/TrjaKrRoAT
I really appreciate a lot about @tryglass
Maybe Musk wants to colonise Mars as he’s running out of places on Earth where he won’t encounter ‘local negativity’ https://t.co/10oFQfMCzR
@sam__rye @mattnormn @matchboxstudio @YunusGriffith @MazzucatoM @IIPP_UCL @CamdenCouncil @IngridBurkett Ha ha … it works for Sweden, though

“The submission argues that the government should do nothing to increase electric vehicle uptake before 2035.” (Shocking levels of wilful denialism, delay, deceit and obfuscation from the ‘traditional’ motor and fuel lobbies, and then gov, here) https://t.co/907pJKH8sa

@thomholbrook @MazzucatoM Perhaps. But if the challenge is quality rail, mission approach (systemic, x-sector/x-disciplines, top-down x bottom-up) not necessary. Couldn’t it simply be innovative public leadership/investment (beyond cost-benefit assessment) as per many of their sustainability strategies?
@egockel I think, given the deaths (current and future) that can be attributed, ‘weapon’ is not too far off the mark. https://t.co/Iog4KXmnr7 and https://t.co/XwYM1VFfAs

@roodave Indeed the backdrop is true, but I feel like that those responses wouldn’t have happened like this a couple of months ago - that behaviour has been waved through, encouraged, and increasingly unmoderated at all. It’s pretty shocking.

No easier way to see how Twitter has become so polluted so quickly than to scan the responses to this straightforward critique of weaponised urban mobility by someone who knows what they’re talking about.

“In the cases of each of these companies—along with similar claims made by hundreds of others—they’re relying on a common, but controversial, form of climate bookkeeping known as “market-based accounting.” (As with offsets, indulgences) https://t.co/O42vQwd62U
@BrentToderian Wakanda — strong street scene, hi-tech and Lo-TEK, excellent public transport, vibrant cultural life https://t.co/3xvC2l88mC

NB: I’m posting a little more frequently over at Mastodon, at danhill@mstdn.social, but not departing here fully (partly to see what happens; partly as showing up here is a small contribution to some actual ‘public square’-like activity, despite M***’s efforts otherwise)

(According to my colleague @filipekjellgren, around 10% of all Swedish municipalities are taking part, demonstrating the value of ‘missions and movements’ key to ‘spreading over scaling’, and tactical urbanism led strategically, reinforcing/transforming roles of gov and citizens)

“The pandemic transformed streets to make them more welcoming for pedestrians and bicyclists. These cities made the change permanent” (Delighted to see our #streetmoves #oneminutecity project here @vinnovase @ArkDesC) https://t.co/JDSzc4OB0A via @citylab

‘The Shortest History of England’, by James Hawes, is great. As with his equivalent on Germany, Hawes is brilliant at explaining how ancient fault lines endlessly shape politics, culture and identity. In particular here, how ‘the UK’, ‘Britain’ and ‘England’ can never hold. https://t.co/eI5TSIywO3

@om @tomcoates @margarethowell @Sunspel Want @om said. The clothes are expensive but I literally have 20 year old shirts from @margarethowell which are still great. The truly sustainable choice! And the service (+ space) is so good; they’ll find you a good fit. Universal Works ditto, and slightly looser cuts actually.

@gquaggiotto @martinsw Japan is the first major #slowdown country; its movement into that, with false starts, resistance, brilliant regeneration and intriguing experiments, is fascinating. Emphasis on land price will need adjusting here, and those outside denser cores need a future too (probably move)
@Fractal10 Of course. Australia lagging well behind there too, but could leapfrog many others if it got its act together.

“On average, new passenger vehicles in Australia have around 20% higher emissions than the United States, and around 40% higher emissions than in Europe.” (Australia has made more progress on SUVs than SDGs in the last decade) https://t.co/cCcb42CZiu
@Nadim_ch @gquaggiotto @sam__rye @mikaelseppala @sentiers @christianbason @ImmyKaur @ChoraFoundation Happy hols!

@mattnormn @matchboxstudio @sam__rye @YunusGriffith @MazzucatoM @IIPP_UCL @CamdenCouncil @IngridBurkett I nodded to that in the book, downplaying targets in favour of looser North Star, constant navigation, adaptation. I prefer the idea of just working with systems/cultures; thus my usual go-to metaphorical terrains: gardening, cooking, football, designing (or Meadows’s dancing)

@mattnormn @matchboxstudio @sam__rye @YunusGriffith @MazzucatoM @IIPP_UCL @CamdenCouncil @IngridBurkett Been thinking about this a lot, since pitching up in Aus again (embarrassing, if not unusual, that we’d barely considered that whilst in Europe). I think all variants on ‘mission’ are similarly problematic, inc challenge, due to linear mode, assumption of completion etc …
@danielyep @ImmyKaur Thanks!
@RIBA @msdsocial More on Jacky's work https://t.co/GGL0Rib5c0

Fantastic that our student Chon Kei (Jacky) Lam was awarded Bronze Medal Commendation in the @RIBA President's Medals. Congrats to my colleagues on Bachelor of Design, esp. Mark Ng & Djordje Stojanovic—and esp. to Jacky, now studying M.Arch at @msdsocial https://t.co/yzXcNdL63X
@odannyboy @covrter @peterme @matterbattle That was a good one
@StockholmCyclo @ArkDesC Ah good to see you both!
@shlmld @liu_universitet @akustrak @fergusbisset @WetterEdman @LiUdesign Interested in your reflections!

Back in July 2022, we (@msdsocial) hosted a talk with @mLokko + @joseph_grima, with four members of our faculty (Anoma Pieris, Alex Felson, Jyoti Shukla, Patrick Cobbinah) RE materiality, circularity, waste, food systems, property, architecture—now online! https://t.co/b2PERvbIIm
@ImmyKaur @ThatNikkiBi @hdl2010 Hope it’s useful!
@RomyRawlings I know it well. Vinnova part-funded it! But a lot easier to work with timber, for many of the things we currently use steel and concrete for.
Advert I just got served whilst googling ‘who did John Major have an affair with’ https://t.co/gI6WE2cGh1

“There is no other commercially viable way to create steel, which we need not only for construction but also to create wind turbines” (Note: check out Modvion’s wooden wind turbines. Stronger, taller, lighter, cheaper—80% reduction in carbon) https://t.co/Z2X8QUsuQn
@inevernu Don’t think I’m swinging by anywhere, sadly (although the carbon involved in actually visiting all cities would be a nightmare) A visit one day, I hope!

“(Al Bayt stadium) designed by Albert Speer, no less. This is not a misprint. It was the firm of Albert Speer Jr, son of the architect of the Third Reich, that just seemed like the best fit to the Supreme Delivery Committee, the best vibe, the best shout” https://t.co/zHrVGmjtkz
Thanks to the World Design Organization folks for appointing me to the World Design Capital 2026 selection committee — will be interesting! https://t.co/h1Lw89vuID
Nice reflection from students who produced our recent exhibit with colleagues in Norway (@AHO_Oslo etc) for Oslo Architecture Triennial https://t.co/DsZ1OKAUyS
@SavvasVerdis @ollywainwright Heat

Adding to this “all-time Twitter usage high” (and such high-quality usage, Elon!) by posting to say that I’m on Mastodon at @danhill@mstdn.social, just FYI … sort of just hanging around, like kids outside a Tesco Express of an evening

MSDx, our summer show at @msdsocial, launched last night. Thanks to all the students and staff, partners and collaborators, who make this happen — amazing work on display! Up for two weeks, come and visit! https://t.co/8QpogEvYMY
@IngstrupMads @avaltone @TanggaardLene There’s a PDF https://t.co/KS0MwRblvR

@dhofstetter_x @avaltone Gets into it, yes (esp value model in Streets, which is now another @vinnovase project in the mission portfolio). But it’s hard - as you know! - as impact is so closely tied to ideologies. I nod to that!
@eccemarco @avaltone You can ask @vinnovase to see if they have any left. Into the second print run now!
@craigmod “PS: You can put it on your Live Journal, MySpace page and blog as well!”
@StockholmCyclo Nice! I like the smoking analogy. Also, ta for the shout-out!

@Davidjmking @sam__rye @YunusGriffith @MazzucatoM @IIPP_UCL @CamdenCouncil @IngridBurkett I think that’s exactly right - but they’re not mutually exclusive; rather, symbiotic. Sometimes the mission can be the macguffin needed to initiate culture change. Sometimes it’s the setting, grounded to avoid worst excesses of abstract change management. Change, prototyped.
@avaltone Great, Anna, kiitos!

@drdrasko @ConversationUK Indeed, could settle at 8.8bn by 2100, almost 2bn fewer than UN suggests. IF - a big IF! - we re-gear things accordingly, this could be an opportunity to rethink and rework things https://t.co/ID4rSOvaYL
Great article on the complex questions of Australian food https://t.co/C8ZyepShg8
@ImmyKaur @sam__rye @byngtown @indy_johar @CassieRobinson On it
Congrats Rob!

@sam__rye @vinnovase Or the role of @ArkDesC in Sweden, which I just wrote about here: https://t.co/2YG4pXKeqM As Australia could be the Nordic region of Asia-Pacific if it wanted to (cough) we’ll need to make something new here

@sam__rye Not easy at all. Hence my 600 page book on the matter! Although that’s full of handy examples (by others, as well as @vinnovase’s). A key issue here is lack of capability in public agencies with right positioning + skills ie DDC, SITRA, DOGA + D-Box, Vinnova across Nordic’s alone

@sam__rye Yunus are doing great work here … though I also feel the ‘how’ is the most important aspect — the theory of change (ie we can’t just email the target to the general population, who then say ‘ah ok then’ and crack on with systemic change at all level.) Yunus would agree I’m sure!
@Pott_Shrigley_ I do enjoy the lack of thick black clouds of soot in this arcadian image

@Davidjmking @sam__rye @YunusGriffith @MazzucatoM @IIPP_UCL @CamdenCouncil @IngridBurkett That implementation is part of the mission - including co-design of the missions with the organisations involved. Missions are not simply target setting (in fact, that’s the least useful aspect, as targets shift) - the mission is the process, the journey https://t.co/KS0MwRblvR
@gquaggiotto It’s an intriguing dilemma isn’t it? 😉
Thanks Drasko!
Great overview by ⁦@msdsocial⁩’s ⁦@anna_hurlimann⁩ ⁦@bushjude⁩ and Georgia Warren-Myers  https://t.co/enU0zId06V

A short piece on the key role of public agencies for public questions, and capacities for working in the gaps, being the cement between the bricks—reflecting on the work, capability, and positioning of @ArkDesC in the Swedish system https://t.co/2YG4pXKeqM

@mattinwales @stevenjmesser @vickytnz Not glib at all. But must go along with work to make it legible, usable, accessible, equitable, tangible etc. And that last one is key to (my understanding) of snowplough: build prototypes which flush out dark matter whilst creating momentum, desire, capability for what follows
@theasnow @sam__rye Sure was. I got to rehearse with you first!
@CallanRowe @matchboxstudio Thanks for organising!

(It is shocking that deals are being negotiated and “agreed to discuss loss and damage on the basis that it doesn’t include compensation or admissions of liability”. Who could honestly suggest that “admissions of liability” are not appropriate?) https://t.co/hVWvMbznTk
@dneus @LaTrioli @cityofmelbourne @LordMayorMelb @abcmelbourne Gneiss

@janchip @theasnow It’s actually free (not sure if @vinnovase can even sell things!) If you email @vinnovase and ask, they might have some left. They did another print run, as the first batch disappeared rapidly - and I’ve no idea how many remain.
@Nadim_ch @theasnow If you email @vinnovase and ask, they might have some! They did another print run, as the first batch disappeared rapidly - and I’ve no idea how many are left!

(Once again, the entire focus of the article is the old 20thC paradigm of energy as something to be moved around, as opposed to something that can stay local, small, distributed. Energy does need moving, natch, but there is new question as to ‘how much?’) https://t.co/JMjlMgNEM4
@theasnow Ah that’s nice! Hope it’s useful

(This could be one of the last tweets I send on this ghost ship — or maybe not, who knows! — but if so, thanks so much for this @ImmyKaur! Much too kind, but really appreciated. Also, thanks to the largesse of the Swedish taxpayer, it’s free!) https://t.co/KS0MwRblvR

@SustainableTall Not him! Rather, the Chief Misanthrope said “l think public transport is painful. It sucks…(No-one likes it)… there’s like a bunch of random strangers, one of who might be a serial killer, OK, great.” (And then he got into a fight about it) https://t.co/fdfaIdUMpZ
(If you’re trying to find OFFICE, which admittedly is not the most internet-friendly name, they’re here https://t.co/KIlClXkQEN They’re great)

(This is such powerful work by Office — congrats to them — who are rapidly becoming one of the most interesting firms around, via a non-profit, retrofit-oriented and participative practice model) https://t.co/y9dYpKBtVk

(This is not good from Manchester City Council — typically perhaps. Night & Day was key for those of us in and around the ‘90s Manchester/Northern Quarter scene. Such scenes must evolve, of course, but lose meaning if they float too free of such moorings) https://t.co/dE2mCp5gop

(This research doesn’t note the need to reduce traffic noise — though it does point to the lack of green space in cities, for us and birds. So let’s reimagine our biggest shared public spaces in cities — our streets — as bird sanctuaries, for us, them, and multiple other things)

(In my relentless varied provocations about reframing ‘value’ of streets, the inverse relationship between traffic noise and birdsong is almost always the research that grabs peoples’ imagination. Here’s yet more research on *some* of what birdsong does) https://t.co/0K2WcHFUbG
“What keeps us going, ultimately, is our love for each other, and our refusal to bow our heads, to accept the verdict, however all-powerful it seems” (RIP, legend) https://t.co/K7QdgBLHgM

“In projects embodying an ethic of care, the architect must redesign the design process itself – moving beyond designing for to designing with.” (On Anthony Clarke’s architecture of care, a beautiful piece by @naomistead) https://t.co/lrFZALDcpW via @SatPaper

@ImmyKaur That’s very kind, Immy, and much appreciated (and returned back atcha, about your work!) I feel like I’ve been unusually ‘head-down’ recently, engaged in understanding a new organisation, context, culture etc, but hope to surface with further thoughts, ideas, insights soon!

@sam__rye Indeed. In the book there’s also sections on speculative narratives, how to use them, etc. And of course, shifting narratives (and thus addressing belief systems, ideologies, motivations) was also core, as we took a design-led approach: design always involves itself in narratives

@ImmyKaur @sam__rye The one-minute city aspect gets a reference in a couple of pages reflecting on building engagement, awareness etc. But could actually be a book in its own right (!!!) and is now a focus of my current work, I guess. Here, it’s just a minor note - but it cut-through globally

@ImmyKaur @sam__rye Thanks v much to both of you - it’s appreciated. I’m going to write more about it sooner or later (haven’t really done that yet) but it was really a case of writing it up as I was going, and then rewriting, reframing etc. So it was very much part of the process of doing.
@sam__rye @ImmyKaur Page one 😬
@ImmyKaur @sam__rye Thanks Immy!

@gregorg @FiveiPads @roryhyde Absolutely. And Dyer is a great example of working with subjective positions and cultural criticism. But although @108 is working very much within its genre/art form, he’s using the medium to critique the medium within another hybrid medium, blurring art and life! Interesting!

@sam__rye Yeah exactly. The ‘one-minute city’ framing of street mission is unpacked in detail, as a social movement tactic there, and more fundamentally the building of ‘communication’ into the practice of co-design and policymaking and mission-setting - not a separate act
@sam__rye Did you check my book on this? https://t.co/KS0MwRblvR Lots of thoughts on technique there… there’s also a bunch of cases at UCL IIPP ie https://t.co/K6xv6t1nFl

@gregorg @FiveiPads I watch them with my son in 40-minute chunks. Rogers has near-total mastery of medium — truth to materials — and Is having fun sketching out a new form of critique. As @roryhyde + I were speculating last night, may even have sthg in common with work by Eva Hagberg + Justin Beal

@gregorg @FiveiPads I can also recommend the (shorter) ‘Death Stranding’ review. And the 3.5 hour ‘Doom’ exposition is excellent. But the ‘Tokimeki Memorial’ review is also in this ‘Boku…’ vein and rewards your service in watching it https://t.co/IZYa8u1Cce
@gregorg That’s the thing!
@rotational @108 Yes, amazing

I’m somewhat obsessed with Tim Rogers’ critical stylings. Amazingly in-depth five-hour reviews of video games, like ‘boku no natsuyasami’, with total mastery of medium. Who or what is the Action Button of architecture and urbanism criticism?  https://t.co/tPTh9PyalI

“One of the great enigmas of ukiyo-e …is the anachronistic intrusion of Western drawing into an apparently closed world; that the sophisticated culture of Edo (now modern Tokyo) seemingly closed off its borders since the Middle Ages” https://t.co/dXRnAfhWB4
@tomcoates @pakschaal @maxgadney I think he knows he might go in and never come out again …

@dariorodighiero @mariofaranda @dannydorling No, none at all! The construction is hopeful at best and extractive, in every sense, at worst. Necessary renovation could be achieved by off-site manufacture using bio based materials, if any real innovation was at play. The rest is empty growth rather than regenerative growth.

@tomcoates @pakschaal @maxgadney Love them. Sadly, @maxgadney doesn’t have the hardware. Slavin and I were chatting about getting together in a game at some point, though. One day! Timezones notwithstanding

@dariorodighiero @mariofaranda I was just pointing out the projection - population halving by 2100 (along with Thailand, Spain, Japan and China etc) At least without significant immigration shift. Read @dannydorling’s ‘slowdown’ for more on that …

@tomcoates @pakschaal I haven’t wandered around something like this for a while (currently I wander around very fictional CoD worlds with @maxgadney on iOS version!). Vicariously enjoying my son’s virtual worlds, though + plotting new architecture courses. Seen this? https://t.co/jWJNuUguZi
@stml @pasnormalstudio @maap_cc @ThePedla Lovely! Man, I love bikes. I swear, if everyone just cycled everywhere for everything we could have world peace

@stml I can imagine @pasnormalstudio is a bit warm, but @maap_cc is suited to Melbourne’s weather, which must be fairly close to Greece, I would’ve thought. Or will be in 20 years! Try @ThePedla for some lightweight stuff. Though a local Greek brand would be good (μααρ?)
@TurnstoneTweets @Pott_Shrigley_ Ware …. He teaches at Sussex, I think, and has a good podcast https://t.co/CdsxtsSGWd

“Natural Resources Institute Finland (Luke) has developed a new and inventive method to produce biobased, sustainable and non-toxic bio-glues that have a potential to replace the formaldehyde-based adhesives in the production of panels” (Thanks Luke) https://t.co/kQQsI5MCqk
@stml https://t.co/jG487LM2E6 or https://t.co/Lh78OejS8T

@jellway Would still benefit from going on a diet. And seems to have avoided any of careful detailing, expressive verve, or recessive minimalism. Doesn’t say much about civic infrastructure or #publicluxury

@jellway The NYC stuff is typically brutish - that city’s public realm is the worst, as if designed for a war zone. The Brisbane one at least look a little more elegant - except for the extraneous bits hanging off them - and are they doing double-duty as street lights?

@jellway Where are the likes of David Mellor https://t.co/aigx06sYFs when you need them? Or rather, the enlightened clients that commission them. I don’t mind things in the street (depending on what they do) but they could at least be generous, elegant, thoughtful, careful

(However, does feel like the traditionally conservative view from this angle is being played out here again: addressing demand and supply together, @RewiringAus, could allow us to avoid many “heavy transmission lines” etc. Draw me the map indicating why that’s needed, otherwise)
“While we’ve historically been highly dependent on fossil fuels, we have also had a competitive advantage in shifting. After all, we have rather a lot of sun, wind and land” https://t.co/kM8b4KZlwI
@AntoAndreoni 100%! Pathetic
@dariorodighiero @mariofaranda (Bearing in mind Italy is on track for a population of 30m by the end of the century—are they all supposed to be living in Milano?!)

@dariorodighiero @mariofaranda Construction is a filthy business! All round, from extraction and logistics through to construction and operation and demolition. The Danish Reduction Roadmap is excellent on the scale of change required https://t.co/QERwawT8FB (including not-building, which would work for Milan)

(Finally, beginning of swing to regenerative #foundationalinfrastructures under public/shared ownership, rather than govts propped up by extractive polluting income like parking fees and land sales to property developers?)

This building was probably one of the first I noticed as ‘architecture’, when it opened in 1981. By the UK government’s Property Services Agency, apparently no one knows the design architect, nor are there any floor plans.

What’s different this time?”

“I want the RIBA to welcome all people who design the built environment, whether it’s in a traditional architecture practice, or a construction consultancy, or working in a local authority body, or even working in a tech startup on new forms of manufacturing” (So good)

Great to see the importance of the good client, and the team — including a shout to the building contractor, Cocksedge — called out both by the architect, Níall McLaughlin, and @ollywainwright, in this fine review of a fine building

“The college created the possibility for success in the way that they initiated and managed the project. The appointment of designers, consultants, builders and craftsmen was treated with care…team was supported and robustly questioned in our decisions.” #goodclient

My bike lanes stayed dry this morning, despite a damp (#understatement) ride home last night - others in our neck of the woods not so fortunate (and outside of Melbourne, in Shepparton and country Victoria, less fortunate again). Incredible amount of rain yesterday.

@peter_hill_ Well, yes, exactly the issue. The language of ‘business case’ should be downstream of the brief, rather than upstream.

… and most policymaking practice (I’m not going to mention much media and politicians). (From another context) this is very good on the need to recognise that everything is context https://t.co/m0I602Qfxo

Which may ultimately be the main useful takeaway. As everything is culture, what works is only ever local and cannot simply be deployed elsewhere. What works in Stockholm may not work in Malmö, never mind Melbourne, Montreal or Manila. Thus the fallacy of ‘what works’ …

But having been there throughout, a lot of it has worked very well, given a more holistic public health agenda was guiding it. I’m so loathed to get into it publicly due to the hysteria stirred up elsewhere, and equally, what worked there will not work anywhere else.

Only posting this as a saw several friends had ‘liked’ it. There are many things to learn from the strategy, and many things unique to Sweden, and many things that have or could turn out to be errors, and all points in between. It’s too early to declare success or failure …

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw It’s not only grounded (although I like Latour’s use of that) but also owned, deeply participative, co-produced, meaning-full, care-full, legible, adaptable, tending to resilient etc etc. That’s a quite different sensibility and practice, I think.

And completely shifting the emphasis there, to resist scaling to abstractions rather than go for it, and instead enable specific places, peoples to construct their own systems, cultures, things (that shifts our role as designers). Learning might be shared, but ground-up

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw @cbr_heartdoc @summerscope Right. Or at least let’s think about scale more carefully ie Murray/Darling requires a response at that scale; a community centre is another scale again. Hence my one-minute city provocation, within 15, within 30 etc etc. (Ta for paper; looks good!)

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw What I meant by ‘lossy’. Each step of abstraction loses detail, creates waste, homogenises etc That’s where the rot sets in, whether a hospital triage process or farming or a public building or a cemetery etc Collaborating on ground-up instead asks good questions about specifics

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw @cbr_heartdoc So I’m querying the idea that homogeneity dropped onto other contexts (the starting comments) is a good idea — and asking for greater specificity with that reality, working with that grain, whether your street, Melbourne, the Murray/Darling etc and resisting careless scaling

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw @cbr_heartdoc It’s how we think about scale in a less hierarchical (or colonial) sense - ie local is interdependent with other scales too, but at least that local or regional scale enables participation, groundedness, diversity rather than homogeneity, adaptation etc

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw So not to say one can’t learn from that ‘reality’ level (which I still have a problem with!) and test that learning elsewhere (some other bit of reality? Recognising it’s all interdependent…) but it’s a very different practice to deploying, scaling, reproducing etc

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw And of course makes problematic a lot of previous/current ideas of industry and commerce! But, we can see where that has led, in most cases, with ‘externalities’ simply ignored in that lossy process. And those externalities, for want of a better word, are social, environmental

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw Precisely. But I’d also say it’s relevant for any ‘design for policymaking’ work (abstracting up only leads to national solutions rather than regional or local specificity, and we can see where that heads) or anything to do with design for living environments, built environment…

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw So I’m getting precisely at that ‘we rendering something somewhere new’ sensibility … (and I know you’re very aware of that, @overlobe, given your location!) Think we have to seriously question many of those instincts, habits or practices now (again, Liboiron worth a read!)

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw Indeed that makes sense for some things, but increasingly clear that perhaps only ground-up (as opposed to ‘scaling’, top-down, or colonialism in certain contexts) would enable or create richer, adaptive, specific, resilient, participative, ethical, diverse possibilities

This article on our website gives the more ‘official view’ of the mission: https://t.co/b19jcP2C6L That includes this aspect of involving multiple players - using the street to bind the system together - before ultimately heavily citizen participation oriented

@hmantymaki @KatjaLindroos @NCitymaking @SitraFund It’s a very different approach to usual urban planning and development (and thus not easy) - drawing from both tactical urbanism and strategic design. Almost ‘anti-planning’. Nothing is guaranteed or predicted, but is creating conditions for things to happen. happy to share more!

@hmantymaki @KatjaLindroos @NCitymaking @SitraFund The model is ‘every street’ as one can’t, with social equity in mind, just choose so@e. So the approach is a multi-part open source toolkit that cities can adopt and adapt. All streets have to transform in time (and they’re all physically connected) so it’s ‘when’ not ‘if’

@hmantymaki @KatjaLindroos @NCitymaking @SitraFund It’s both a leap, and a serious mission :) We’re just starting phase 2 of Street Moves now, folding in several more cities working with the same modular kit. Plus a new value model research, into new planning tools etc, and some related work on charging infrastructures …

Good article, generally, on the issue of ‘gearing’ economies like Australia’s (we might add Sweden’s) to global players like China. Keywords are ‘slowing growth’. Not meltdown, as usually suggested: slower growth is an opportunity. But only if re-geared. https://t.co/agB57kYgLS

Addressing a range of scenarios there would question some of the other ‘certainties’ ie need for natural gas. Similarly, nuclear may well have a role, as some component of backup baseload, but perhaps not two extra new plants. And so on.

Or, might we see scenarios other than the constant projected doubling of demand for power? Given population slowdown, growth slowdown, and actual efficiency measures (systemically designed to avoid Jevons Paradox) why this doubling of demand? (Other than shareholder return?)

e.g. batteries may work better at block, street, neighbourhood scale—breaking the individualistic British approach of house-scale power-plants creates other problems (e.g. boiler problem, insulation problem, wheelie bin wars!) with storage and generation both shared and discrete

@noelito @IndyJohar (But am no expert on that, and have not thought about it specifically! That’s a big caveat being applied. But that’s how I see the scales are useful, maybe and of course they’re all connected/nested ie do that 1 min scale well and we can manage 15 and 60 min a lot better)

@noelito @IndyJohar Shared Mobility:

60 minute: metro/subway
30 minute: bus/tram
15 minute: shuttle, e-bike 
1 minute: foot, wheelchair, bike
Etc 

You can’t have a subway at 1 minute or 15 minute scale, just as few can walk or roll for 60 minute scale. So it may help us think these things through

@noelito @IndyJohar I suggested one-minute city in response to 15, and then pushed out to those wider scales, to get across these systemic connections, and broader theory of urban organisation. We can push it across the categories I suggested and many more eg.

@noelito @IndyJohar So again, blurring and shifting relationships between those different cultures of decision-making - not at all hard boundaries - but they more from representative to participative, from common to diverse, from big to small, heavy to light, slow to fast, fixed to@malleable etc

@noelito @IndyJohar Or religion:

60 minute: city cathedral/mosque
30 minute: major synagogue
15 minute: local chapel
1 minute: Shinto shrine tucked between two buildings in a side street …

… and so on

@noelito @IndyJohar Or football:

60 minute: big stadium
30 minute: sports centre
15 minute: school pitches used by communities around 
1 minute: kids playing in street

@noelito @IndyJohar eg We can stretch organisation of ‘health’ across these nested relationships:

60 minute: major hospital
30 minute: health centre
15 minute: doctors’ surgeries
1 minute: trees, neighbours

Lower are more participative, malleable; former are more representative, ‘heavier’

@noelito @IndyJohar Def. I guess I’m reinforcing that the 15 minute scale is bit more about the municipality, by definition. Not fully, the the emphasis skews there. You can cycle a long way in 15 mins (3km?) and so your relationship is not so intimate, involved. Health stretches across those scales
@noelito @IndyJohar Need to write all this up! There’s something emerging, as nested organisation of scales and paces, and I’ll need to write it and draw it to figure it out properly …

@noelito @IndyJohar That moves up through the gears from that point - 1’, 15’, 30’, 60’ etc - with representative decision making cultures at latter larger scales (subways, stadia, cathedrals, hospital etc) and participative at smaller scale (bike, street football, shrine, tree)

@noelito @IndyJohar … and thus those must be participative and constructed by people themselves - which is appropriate at neighbourhood scale, block scale, street scale ie one-minute … which means more participative model, people author/grow their own city at that scale and intimacy

@noelito @IndyJohar So it must average out, by definition, which is why the concept is very strong way of thinking about municipal services, amenities, infrastructures etc. It’s very useful in that respect. But for increased diverse and differentiated experiences you need to zoom in …

@noelito @IndyJohar The interesting thing about 15 mins City if from peoples’ perspective (needs/desires) is that there’d be infinite overlapping, constantly shifting views (as needs change, and people are different.) So it’s not really a tightly defined district. That’s v powerful. But also tricky

@noelito @IndyJohar I’ve written a narrative, a few years ago for Melbourne, which is more from neighbourhood view (actually, many variations on it, but the Melbourne one is most developed), covering 24 hours. I’ll post this weekend, I think.

@noelito @IndyJohar That’s less-likely, as the 15-minute view IS from the point of view of the neighbourhood, actually the municipality. It’s from that perspective, by definition. You need one-minute perspective (temporal and spatial) to get down to street level, person/animal level …

@debcha What I’ve found, when trying to get these ideas through (eg urban projects in Amsterdam, Stockholm, London etc) is that the old guard of big infra/planning resists this hugely - for obvious reasons perhaps. And it will mean a huge transfer of value I suspect. But not a total one.

@debcha Totally. There could be such a powerful, meaningful relationship between a baseload/backup layer from centralised structures (also socially binding across places) and then distributed/super-local for variable loads ‘on top’. Maps onto mobility, energy, waste, maybe water etc

@biancawylie @debcha Again, the interplay between community/place and public/society, mapping against non-grid and grid, variously, allowing for diverse scales of decision-making, ownership, culture, material, resource flows etc ... (The awkward ghost at the feast there is usually the private sector)

@biancawylie @debcha Definitely. But good mess! Also residual power and meaning of retaining assets in public, depending on the positioning of what public means (which is different in Sweden to Canada, never mind other places) — but a different kind of public alluded to in my 'al masha' reference

@biancawylie @debcha There, I quote Walter Hood & Grace Mitchell Tada, from their 'Black Landscapes Matter': "Attention to the everyday and mundane recognizes what already exists around us, and activates the space between its “things” and its people" ie. 'infra', in which we can activate the mundane

@biancawylie @debcha but also seeing public space, or shared space, as infrastructure too — at least in this reframing of infrastructure as social, cultural and political ie. the beauty, dignity and utility of shared things in everyday life https://t.co/4YOlN5NGO6

(Key balancing act here, beautifully alluded to by @debcha, may be this evolving relationship between the super-local possibilities of distributed infrastructures and the greater-than-the-sum broader “infrastructural citizenship” at scale, connecting us all. Grid + non-grid.)

@happy_roman @BicycleDutch @Cycling_Embassy Sure, that’s all fab! But there’s still that small niche too. Given its roof, heating, weatherproofing, more space (for kit or groups of people), slow, quiet, renewably-powered, on demand, shared + low running costs means it could be owned by a neighbourhood, or co-op.

My sense if there’s a good niche for these small shuttles (off peak, for those whose mobility needs cannot be served by bikes, running in and between neighbourhoods, in the gaps left by mass transit and active transport) but only a niche. Are niches enough to cover R&D costs?

@TAOWhiteboard @GuSv01 @StockholmCyclo @theoverheadwire @MikeLydon @skyejduncan I'm suggesting the pavement is too important to relegate to questions of charging and power — so if we limit vehicles in the first place (and thus free up parking) the street is reclaimed as public space; can find room for a bit of charging there (if flexible) + rest in buildings

@StockholmCyclo @theoverheadwire @MikeLydon @skyejduncan Either grid operators/service providers would likely be interested in this, or shared mobility providers (or both working together). This on the basis again that the street is primarily shared vehicle (with private charging done off-street in underground garages, driveways etc)

@StockholmCyclo @theoverheadwire @MikeLydon @skyejduncan Given rate of change in battery tech, and variable supply (renewables) and variable demand (vehicles), and need to keep streets free of vehicle-related infrastructure, this might be a better lightweight, 'adaptive design' solution to explore. Would handle much small-to-medium

@StockholmCyclo @theoverheadwire @MikeLydon @skyejduncan I would add to this that there is likely also huge benefit in disconnecting charging from the grid ie. having 'floating' charged batteries which are sent out on demand to certain points to provide local boosts (can be moved on e-cargo bike even) which provides flexibility
@GuSv01 @StockholmCyclo @theoverheadwire @MikeLydon @skyejduncan Existing parking space is a good starting point for that question, I think. Can’t be pavement.

@eversion Can you put the infrastructure in the park, so the crew can just turn up? I know that requires joined-up coordination usually outside scope of project, but that’s the trick. And would change the game elsewhere. We explored this with early Sidewalk Labs. Easy to say, I know...

On several big urban plans I worked on I learned from our fire engineers that we rarely need fire engines as contemporary buildings basically don’t burn (if they are, they’re built wrong). Old buildings have water and equipment installed nearby, so you can simply move the crew.

This is great. So many streets or garden projects are shut down with “but what about getting a fire engine down there?”. In most cases they’re not necessary (and increasingly). Small pieces, loosely joined assembled in situ again

@oconnorjustin13 Yes, amazing. Fascinated by the complex form of industrial strategy going on here (easing and damping incentives and laws for electric vehicles) alongside entrepreneurial activity around modular supply chains.

Also: I don’t think tiny electric cars should be ‘the future’ vs bikes + public transit + active transport; when I say shared cars I don’t mean Uber; I do think tiny adaptable EVs are better than larger wasteful EVs, particularly if local, shared, diverse, recyclable

... as well as describing an alternate tech culture to Silicon Valley’s often toxic approaches (in particular, the adulation of Tesla, which pursues its 20th century model of mobility into the ground, creating as many problems as it solves...)

On the tech itself, the article is great for describing the ecosystem around it, and its adaptable, versatile nature, + role of Chinese state in clever damping and releasing of incentives (perhaps a far more sophisticated form of industrial strategy than we have words for) ...

(Also, had to remind myself about two things concerning Twitter: point out that tweeting a story is not necessarily endorsing the technology it’s describing; don’t ever engage in what purports to be debate on Twitter, given every pixel of the platform is geared towards damage)

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Note my comment on Sweden model (and same other in Nordics, much of Europe etc) is before a significant shift towards circular material use. When I moved here two years ago it was clear there’s already way less plastic etc in circulation than U.K., but still a way to go here too

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Nee build at apartment scale (or under streets) automated vacuum disposal though I’m not a fan as it’s not adaptive (cf Japanese building lifespan note), expensive, and does nothing to have people confront their waste. Would rather simpler model which builds social fabric

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger No wheelie bins on streets at all this way, including on old streets of some equally old buildings. This is precisely how it works in Sweden and gets 99% recycling (although we then wreck the picture a bit by burning it for energy which is not great in other ways.)

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger 2) Build recycling bins at neighbourhood-scale, which people walk their smaller leftovers to through now-pleasant streets (how it happens across much of Europe) Make these engaging community hubs. Smaller electric trucks (increasingly automated) can pick up at ~3am.

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger That means 1) reducing waste massively by enforcing only reusable or biodegradable packaging (legislation and incentive on supplier side, through to retail). Ensure composting/fermentation for food. Build repair and reuse services in your rapidly emptying high street spaces.

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Back to bins (where we came in) the real answer is not architecture narrowly oriented around buildings, but assessing the architecture of the problem. A mission-led approach would tackle the source (materials, waste, consumption patterns, culture, and built fabric)

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Hard to see how either of those happen, given the lack of desire and awareness politically. It would need a mission-led approach - the architects and engineers are skilled enough (if largely taught the wrong things, given politics) People would be into it. Not a technical problem

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger However, instead, British new build is appalling quality, generally. Carmona at UCL produced sobering research here https://t.co/2FCOJkuG2Y Need better new build, and then quality retrofit - which has to be done at scale, given the largely terrible old buildings most live in

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Good. U.K. generally has oldest building stock in Europe, so is a bit odd. For new build, it’d be equally interesting to pursue a circular materials version of Japanese model, where building life is ~27 years. That way buildings are more flexible skins around our living patterns

I call this a 'snowball principle', in which experiments and prototypes designed to scale generate compelling evidence as they go (if you help), thus opening up the strong possibility of building political capital (and so fiscal policy scaffolding) over time rather than at step 1 https://t.co/WrE5TwpNAb

The other side is in locating, initiating, nurturing, driving and spreading small scale changes into portfolios. That's where we've started — which means a broader playbook of social, cultural and technological measures, around which a fiscal scaffolding can subsequently emerge.

This is v important; it indicates one side of the equation — concerning fiscal measures of tax and subsidies — is proven, here at least, given different evaluation, and starting point of small scale changes that tip upwards.

"Similarly, the opportunity to activate upward-scaling tipping cascades will be missed if the value of decarbonisation policies is judged only on their immediate effects." So the tendency to immediate effects is counter-productive (need long term view + thus different evaluation)

"If carbon prices are set equal to some estimated ‘social cost of carbon’, based on the concept of ‘pricing the externality’ of dangerous climate change these opportunities could easily be missed. The finding and activation of decarbonisation tipping points offers an alternative"

First, that "tax and subsidy policies that bring clean technologies below the threshold of cost-parity with fossil fuel technologies can lead to disproportionately rapid decarbonisation, when applied in a context of other supporting policies."

@anthonymobile I think more than Brexit - but yes, Brexit a factor. General slowdown patterns (falling population rates everywhere), growth not well-handled, other options due to tech etc. As usual, not one driver but multiple combining. And not all bad, I think. A chance to reboot.

Similar falls in New York and San Francisco, I would guess — and again, not caused by Covid, but accelerated (SF’s challenges were well-known pre-Covid, ditto NYC with many half-empty new towers.) Broader slowdown patterns.

@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife ... in fact it’s hard to avoid, given nature of time, space, matter and culture! @Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife Iterative development! Assessed against the outcomes you’re shouting for (not the previous set) and delivering rich insights against which you can constantly recalibrate North Stars and compass. My point is iterative development, if building something, isn’t the problem ...

@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife ... but rather, with a systems viewpoint of Meadow’s leverage points hierarchy, not putting paradigm on the exam table. That, indeed, would not enable systemic change. But if you do assess systemic change, via paradigm change - eg radical swing to coops - what’s next steps? ...

@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife I think the key thing is in what you’re saying (“revolution” - or perhaps transformation) and what @CassieRobinson said earlier about insights from iterative development judged against ‘old’ metrics. Both key. But that’s nothing to do with iterative work in itself ...

@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife You can’t do prototyping without thinking about systems (well, one probably could - but one shouldn’t.) In fact, systems are what you’re prototyping. Always (consciously or unconsciously - but hopefully consciously!) System prototypes, developed iteratively, could get you there

@CassieRobinson @Stef_W @catdrew_ @jeneralife Don’t run and type! I’m just saying, it’s hard to avoid iterative when it comes to design and delivery (of course, in various flavours). ‘Incremental’ perhaps has a different meaning, conceptually, arguably implying not addressing transformation deeply enough or quickly enough.

@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife Doesn’t mean you can’t try completely new approaches. Let’s say it was kickstarting a cooperative housing revolution in the U.K., for example. You’d still prototype and test and build an agile, adaptive, iterative practice, as soon as you got near design (stage -1). Right?
@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife The alternative? Knock down and rebuild? Destroy? Circumvent?

@Stef_W @CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife I don’t think they’re mutually exclusive. All iterative means is a certain dynamic - designing and developing based on feedback loops from prototyping and testing. Hard to see how you can’t do that. That’s how you would transform an existing system, in many (most?) cases.

@CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife That’s good. But also a tricky business, this; there is value in iterative approaches to transformation (ie building with, and retrofitting, existing systems, from within. We have so much value sunk in systems (in our examples, streets and school foods) we have to rework them.)

This is one of the clear motives behind the ‘one-minute city’ theory and practice: to better understand, and show, how to radically increase biodiversity around us, in order to continually regenerate biodiversity (including us)

Even if a proxy, as this is across 26,000 Europeans across different contexts “it may prove that managing for bird diversity is a win-win strategy, with both humans and birds benefitting from management actions that promote a high diversity of natural landscape features”

Obviously there are caveats, and the usual causation/correlation issues, particularly with something as ‘slippery’ (flighty?) as researching the presence and impact of bird species across spatial dimensions, but still, the researchers address that as best they can at this point

“An increase in bird species richness by 10% (equivalent to approx. 14 bird species at the median of 136 bird species) is related to an increase in life-satisfaction by a value of 0.052, while an increase in income by 10%” (Birds versus salaries?)

“Our results show that bird species richness is positively associated with life-satisfaction across Europe ... the effect of bird species richness on life-satisfaction may be of similar magnitude to that of income.” (Well, this is interesting) https://t.co/GwTi05yQRx

@prosocialplace @timrgill That detail doesn’t come across the article (which nonetheless does a great job!) but is key to the whole thing. These half-steps are designed to float on the street. @prosocialplace @timrgill In the end, they get removed (and planted somewhere else, as they’re modular, hackable, circular; hence made out of wood) and they get replaced by more@through and bespoke interventions - like putting down roots. @prosocialplace @timrgill Totally agree. But we very rarely get to jump straight to those ‘proper’ retrofits. Too many issues in the way (social, political, financial). Removing the Netherlands’ ubiquitous tiles from front gardens is part of a broader initiative to expand green space in several Dutch cities https://t.co/vyl24YjO1E via @citylab (On a similar theme, this is also great work in Rotterdam — cities, let's keep up the momentum!)

+ of course the great @filipekjellgren at @vinnovase, without whom none of this happens, + able support from many others at Vinnova too. Those are the first steps: 2021 tests models for scaling, adapting and adopting, via more real prototypes out in public (in diff. conditions!)

@ArkDesC Think Tank (esp. @DanielBystrom) doing a lot of work on the ground, w/ great design work from @LundbergDesign + team, + @Utopia_ark,  as well as broader design work by @StockholmCyclo and team at Spacescape, @whitearkitekter et al + @ViableCities for strategic scaling

Many collaborators involved, primarily in the city teams in Stockholm, and soon Malmö, Helsingborg, Göteborg and beyond etc., with the systemic change possibilities via having Transportstyrelsen on board, and a broader reference group including Volvo M, Voi, Ericsson etc.
For more background on the project, you can read the #slowdownpapers description of it https://t.co/krAWcatGzH That, and the surrounding papers, dig further into some of the influences.
